metadata.title: Myocardial Infarction
anatomical location body part affected: Heart/myocardium, coronary arteries;ventricular function is reduced often
description: The atherothromboticischemic type of acute myocardial infarction (MI) is often a life-threatening  event. Prolonged obstruction of coronary blood flow (i.e., myocardial ischemia) commonly results in failure of adequate heart muscle contraction. Complete cellular death in the affected myocardium of a type 1 MI may take 2 to 4 hours, depending mostly on the amount of collateral blood flow around the coronary obstruction. In the clinical settingcardiac biomarker changes with at least one value above the 99th percentile occur, accompanied by several typical findings(1) –Symptoms of angina due to prolonged insufficient coronary artery blood flow –New or presumed-new  abnormal findings on the electrocardiogram (ECG), such as ST-segment  and T-wave changes or new left bundle branch block (LBBB) ST-segment elevation on the ECG is characteristic of acute transmural infarction. ST elevation MI (STEMI) is often followed by the development of pathological Q waves after scarring of the necrotic area –Imaging evidence of new loss of viable myocardium or new left ventricle (LV) regional wall motion abnormality –Identification of an intracoronary artery thrombus by angiography or autopsy –Symptoms of acute MI followed by cardiac death, but the person died before obtaining the cardiac biomarkers or before the increase in biomarker values –Stent thrombosis (in persons with prior stent placement) associated with MI when detected by coronary angiography or autopsy in the setting of myocardial ischemia and with a rise and/or fall of cardiac biomarker values –Coronary artery bypass grafting-related  MI is usually defined by elevation of biomarkers in patients with normal baseline cardiac troponin (cTn) values, in addition to -new pathological Q waves or new LBBB, angiographic documentation of new graft or new native coronary artery occlusion, or imaging evidence of new loss of viable myocardium or new regional wall motion abnormality

Ischemic ST-segment  depression with T-wave  changes characterizes the non-STEMI (NSTEMI) or type 2 MI. Lacking characteristic ST-segment elevation, such patients are typically not triaged for immediate transfer to the catheterization laboratory and, therefore, often receive less primary percutaneous coronary angioplasty. When referred to cardiac rehabilitation, patients with NSTEMI have similar existential anxiety about their heart health as STEMI patients(2,19)

Prior MI or non-acute  MI is evidenced by(1) –Pathological Q waves, usually without symptoms, in the absence of acute ischemic events –Imaging evidence of a region of loss of viable myocardium that is thinned and fails to contract (i.e., abnormal ventricular wall motion). Pathological findings of a prior MI include fibrosis and dense collagenous scar formation in the myocardium

Approximately 7.5 million persons living in the United States are MI survivors.(2) Estimates of the annual incidence of MI in the United States range from 600,000 new and 320,000 recurrent attacksto1.5 million cases(15)
Strong evidence supports the implementation of exercise-based  cardiac rehabilitation for reducing the risk of cardiovascular mortality after MI(17)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage. Insurance coverage for medically supervised cardiac rehabilitation varies for each state and between companies. Some policies cover only a limited number of outpatient sessions, while others cover an entire 12-week  program. No specific special agencies are applicable for this condition
presentation signs and symptoms: In addition to the findings given in the description above, patients may present with(1) –Angina; usually chest pain near the sternum, but variant angina (such as pain in the arm or jaw) is not uncommon –Shortness of breath –Syncope, acute confusion, palpitations, and light-headedness –Stroke  –Abdominal pain

Vital signs may show changes(15) –Increased heart rate (HR) and irregular pulse rate –Blood pressure (BP) is often initially elevated -Right ventricular MI or severe LV dysfunction results in decreased BP –Breathing rate increased –Possible coughing, wheezing, frothy sputum –Fever within 24 to 48 hours after MI

Older adult patients have greater incidence of very poor LV pumping action (cardiogenic shock) during acute STEMI.(3) Broader use of percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) in older adult patients with acute MI reduces mortality (3,4)

Additionally, patients over the age of 75 years and patients with diabetes mellitus, impaired renal function, and dementia have atypical symptoms more frequently(1) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Terminate the evaluation if the patient begins experiencing any cardiac symptomsand immediately contact the supervising physician

Terminate the evaluation and contact the referring physician if resting vital signs become abnormal and –HR more than 25% above the usual resting HR(1) –systolic or diastolic BP greater than 25 mmHg above the usual resting pressure(1) –O2 saturation less than 95% (acceptable value may vary clinically)(1)
Exercise testing is contraindicated when resting systolic BP is more than 200 mmHg and/or diastolic BP is more than 110 mmHg

causes: The primary underlying etiology of MI is atherosclerotic coronary artery disease (CAD) with luminal narrowing. Ruptureof an atherosclerotic coronary plaque and subsequent formation of an occlusive thrombus is the proximate cause oftransmural ischemia and the onset of signs and symptoms of MI(1,15)
Less frequently, myocardial hypoxia may cause MI, even though coronary blood flow is not 100% blocked(2)

Acute cardiac events that include myocardial ischemia and MI may be triggered by heavy physical exertion and emotionalstress that cause myocardial oxygen supply-demand  imbalance (i.e., O 2demand exceeds O 2 supply)(2,18)
pathogenesis: Pathological findings in type 1 MI include atherosclerotic plaque rupture, ulceration, fissuring, erosion, or dissection thatforms a thrombus which completely occludes one or more of the major coronary arteries(4)
Values for high-sensitivity  cTnabove the 99th percentile upper reference limit of 15 ng/L for men and 10 ng/L for womenare commonly usedto assess suspected MI in the acute-care setting(5)

The typical causes of myocardial ischemia in type 2 MI are(2)–increased myocardial O 2demand that disrupts supply-demand  balance in patients with high-grade  but fixed coronaryatherosclerosis–decreased myocardial O 2supply due to coronary artery vasospasm and/or endothelial dysfunction in patients withouthigh-grade  coronary atherosclerosis
In both type 1 and type 2 MI, prolonged myocardial oxygen-supply demand imbalance is the initial step in the developmentof cellular anoxia leading to necrosis(1,2)
If the infarct area is not reperfused with collateral blood supply or revascularized by percutaneous coronary interventionwithin 4 hours, the ischemic myocardium at risk usually becomes necrotic(1,2)
“Remodeling” of the scarred left ventricle after MI takes place over weeks to months. The remodeled ventricle is enlarged,more spherical, and has the risk of arrhythmias heightened (1,16)
risk factors: Type D personality (e.g., components include depression, anxiety, and low subjective quality of life)
Genetic predisposition to the early development of CAD

Increased risk during episodic physicaland sexualactivity appears to be strongly reduced by habitual physical exertion; i.e.,individuals with low habitual physical activity have increased the risk further increased during episodic activity(2)

Physical activity and anger or emotional upset(18)–Authors of an international case-control  study (n = 12,461 cases of acute MI in 52 countries) found that13.6% engaged inphysical activity and 14.4% were angry or emotionally upset 1 hour before symptom onset

overall contraindications precautions: Monitor vital signs and the patient’s symptoms closely during all physical activity to avoid overexertion
Adhere to any specific restrictions/precautions provided by the surgeon/cardiologist
Be aware of the sideeffects of prescribed medications
A common restriction patients are givenduring early post-MI  convalescence is to not lift more than 5 to 10 pounds

Exercise is contraindicated in the following cases:(1) Unstable angina(1) ECG showing new signs of evolving MI(1) Arterial oxygen (P aO2) saturation less than85% or less than 60 mmHg(1) Hemoglobin less than 8 g/dl(1) Hematocrit less than 26%(1) Severe aortic outflow obstruction(1) Suspected or known dissecting aneurysm(1) Acute myocarditis, pericarditis(1) Uncontrolled complex arrhythmias(1) Severe heart failure(1) Recent pulmonary embolus or thrombophlebitis(1) Untreated 3rd-degree  heart block(1) Uncontrolled diabetes(1) Acute infections(1) Digoxin toxicity(1) Severe aortic stenosis or obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy Persistent hypotension: systolic BP less than 90 mmHg Uncontrolled hypertension: resting systolic BP greater than 200 mmHg, and/or resting diastolic BP greater than 105–110 mmHg
Instruct patient to avoid intense Valsalva maneuver or breath-holding  at all times during evaluation and treatment. Encourage appropriate breathing techniques during all physical activity
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

Terminate the evaluation and contact the referring physician if resting vital signs become abnormal and –HR more than 25% above the usual resting HR(1) –systolic or diastolic BP greater than 25 mmHg above the usual resting pressure(1) –O2 saturation less than 95% (acceptable value may vary clinically)(1)
Exercise testing is contraindicated when resting systolic BP is more than 200 mmHg and/or diastolic BP is more than 110 mmHg

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Determine circumstances in which MI occurred; identify what risk factors were present then and now. Have there been any further CAD complications up to this point?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management for MI includes administration of medications and cardiac rehabilitation. Surgery (coronary artery bypass graft and percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty and stenting) is commonly indicated
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications have been prescribed and whether they are taken Medications commonly prescribed after acute MI include aspirin, intravenous (IV) heparin, IV morphine, calcium channel blockers, angiotensinconverting  enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, and beta-blockers(1,6) Thrombolytics may be used in immediately after acute MI(6) Aspirin therapy may also be used in acute conditions(1) Some medications such as beta-blockers  can reduce the HR and BP responses to exercise. Target HR in the exercise prescription may need to be adjusted if such responses are observed during exercise testing Antiplatelet therapy Statins
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:
ECG: Abnormalities include ST-segment depression or elevation and Q waves
Laboratory testing: cTn(I and T) levels are elevated in type 1 MI. Usually,creatine kinase (CK)-MB  and lactate dehydrogenase (LD) levels are elevated after MI(1)
Echocardiogram is often performed in the acute setting to measure cardiac function(1)
PET scans are used to detect MI, but currentlycardiac MRI is favored due to its ability to detect a smaller MI without using radiation(1)
Pulmonary function testing may be conducted in individuals with dyspnea, especially in the presence of comorbid lung disease
A submaximal exercise stress test may be administered at hospital discharge to determine the safety of physical activity and for early exercise prescription
Outpatient cardiac stress testing may be performed to evaluate cardiovascular responses to exercise after MI
ECG, BP, and oxygen saturation are monitored while patient exercises, typically on the treadmill or stationary exercise bicycle
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies. Patients may have outdated or preconceived ideas about treatment for MI. For example, in the past, patients were put on bed rest and instructed to minimize physical activity for several weeks, whereas now much shorter periods of rest are recommended(6)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms are aggravated or eased). If the patient has a history of angina, what activities aggravate the patient’s symptoms? Ask whether the patient ever has chest pain, dizziness, or shortness of breath during or after activity or exercise
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms if appropriate. Ask whether the patient has ever felt pain in jaw or down left arm in combination with chest pain that may indicate atypical angina
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms if present (e.g., pressure vs. tightness, shortness of breath). Document whether the patient has felt unusually tired. Does the patient report palpitations, rapid heartbeat, nausea, sweating, or heartburn?
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if the pain is present now and how much). The Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Scale can be used to rate perceived exertion during physical activity
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night) and also document changes in symptoms resulting from weather or other external variables. Abrupt changes in  the pattern of angina symptoms, such as a change in frequency or duration or a decreased threshold of stimulus, could indicate pre-infarction  angina requiring immediate medical follow-up
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Does the patient have a history of sleep disturbance? If so, why? Does the patient experience paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (waking up gasping for air) or orthopnea (needs more than one pillow to breathe comfortably)?
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to the physician (e.g., angina pectoris). Anxiety is a common psychological symptom following an acute MI
history of present illness.respiratory status: Does the patient require supplemental oxygen? Does the patient have dyspnea? -Individuals who have sustained an MI can present with reduced ventilator efficiency, which contributes to increased dyspnea upon exertion Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _____________________ -Patient’s inability to self-monitor  his or her HR may be a limiting factor for participation in an exercise program

past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cerebrovascular disease, peripheral vascular disease, cancer, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, depression, anxiety, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing Signs and symptoms of dysfunction/disease in other systems (e.g., musculoskeletal, genitourinary, gastrointestinal) might be cardiovascular in origin Inquire about musculoskeletal pain or fatigue, myalgia, claudication, weight change, decreased urinary output, nausea, productive cough, changes in vision, etc.

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: What is the patient’s occupation and what is the job description? What restrictions has patient’s physician placed on activities? Patients with uncomplicated MI may drive a car after 1 to 2 weeks and return to work at 2 to 4 weeks, but those with complicated MI may be restricted longer(7)
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document prior and current functional level as reported by patient and family
social and occupational history.living environment: Number of stairs and floors in the home, with whom patient lives (e.g., caregivers, family members). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home and if any modifications are necessary

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Determine height, weight, BMI, and waist circumference. Obesity is a risk factor for MI and cardiac disease. If present, measure peripheral edema circumferentially or volumetricallyDocument patient’s orientation to time, place, and situation. Is patient alert or lethargic? Mental status changes or confusion might be signs of myocardial ischemia, particularly in older women(7)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Does the patient currently utilize assistive or adaptive devices? If so, are they appropriate? Are new devices indicated?
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Assess based on the level of physical activity level post-MI. The 6-minute  walk for distance test (6MWT) can be used to assess mobility and endurance for stable, nonacute outpatients

Monitor the following at rest, in sitting, in standing, with ADLs, during and after gait, and after a rest period  -BP, heart sounds, HR -ECG for abnormal heart rhythm -O2 saturation value should be more than 95% at rest but may vary by individual

Aerobic exercise intensity may be assessed based on HR, workload metabolic equivalents (METs), or perceived exertion(8) -Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Scale may be used to measure patient’s subjective exercise intensity. Has been shown to correlate linearly with HR and pulmonary oxygen consumption(8)
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Screen radial and dorsalispedis pulsesAssess for appropriate lifting technique, appropriate breathing when lifting, and compliance with weight restrictionsIn the acute phase during a hospital stay, transfers and functional mobility may be impaired. Assess as indicated; may utilize the FIM
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess for abnormalities and need for the assistive device. Document any shortness of breath, pallor, cyanosis, or diaphoresis during ambulation. Provide immediate rest if these should occur. Document vital signs before, during, and immediately after ambulation. Also, document time required to recover to normal resting values. Assess safety with Dynamic Gait Index (DGI)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Perform a gross assessment to identify any existing areas of weakness. Manual muscle testing (MMT) may need to be delayed depending on time since MI and physician’s orders
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to the diagnosisStandardized testing may be performed to identify individual patient concerns, goals, anxiety, or depression. Examples include Cantril Ladder of Life and the Quality of Life Index (QLI)(7) –Other standardized tests that apply to this condition include the Seattle Angina Questionnaire, the Health Belief Questionnaire, and the Cardiac Event Threat Questionnaire

contraindications precautions: Less than 1 to 2 days after acute MI(1)
ECG showing new signs/symptoms of MI(1)
Severe aortic stenosis or obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy(1)
Persistent hypotension: systolic BP less than 90 mmHg(1)
Uncontrolled hypertension: resting systolic BP more than 200 mmHg, resting diastolic BP more than 105110  mmHg(1)
Lifting restrictions, often limited to 510  lbs initially, should be adhered to at all times during early recovery period (i.e., until after remodeling phase)
other: In addition to monitoring symptoms,observe vital signs during physical activity and exercise, especially during the first several weeks: monitor BP, HR, RPE, and fatigue level

Low-risk  patients recovering at home after MI should exercise for at least 30 minutes consisting of moderate aerobic activity such as walking or stationary cycling at least 3 to 4 times per week. Moderate to high-risk  patients should always be monitored when beginning an exercise program(8)

Patients participating in aquatic exercise therapy should remain in an upright position and submerge body no deeper than the xiphoid process. Obtain physician’s clearance for aquatic therapy and recommendations regarding water temperature and time spent in the pool. The patient should be monitored closely for cardiac symptoms and changes in vital signs(8)
Allow adequate rest periods between sets when performing resistance activities in later phases of cardiac rehabilitation programs, generally 30 to 90 seconds(8)

Any activities that increase intra-abdominal  pressure (e.g., Valsalva maneuver) are not recommended. Exercises that compress the abdomen (dead lifts, full squats, knee curls lying on bench): since the increases in such pressure may result in bradycardia(1,8)

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols(8)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: MI or risk factors that may contribute to poor overall health and cardiac function (e.g., obesity, increased cholesterol, tobacco smoking), and lack of regular exercise to promote better health. Post-MI  patients require detailed instruction and/or direct supervision for the safe implementation and progression of an exercise training program Rule out  (1,15) Causes of chest pain that are immediately life-threatening –Dissecting thoracic aortic aneurysm –Pulmonary embolism (PE) –Esophageal rupture –Tension pneumothorax Other causes of chest pain –Musculoskeletal causes (e.g., costochondritis, chest wall trauma, myositis, muscle strain) –Pulmonary causes (e.g., pulmonary hypertension, pleurisy, pneumothorax, pneumonia) –Gastrointestinal causes (e.g., peptic ulcer disease, pancreatitis, esophageal spasm, reflux, cholecystitis, cholelithiasis) –Neurologic causes (e.g., cervical radiculopathy, herpes zoster) –Psychogenic (e.g., panic attacks, somatization disorder) –Other etiology (e.g., sickle cell crisis, herpes zoster) Other causes of CK-MB  elevations –Myocarditis –Cardiac contusion –Cardiac catheterizations –Electrical cardioversion –Cardiac surgery –Muscular dystrophy –Renal failure –Rhabdomyolysis –Surgery involving skeletal muscle –Cesarean section –Athletic activity  –Left ventricular aneurysm –Pericarditis –Left ventricular hypertrophy with strain (in lead V1) –Hyperkalemia more than 8.0 –LBBB –Early repolarization
prognosis: MI is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in the United States.(1,2) Cardiac rehabilitation programs after MI are associated with reduced long-term  complications and mortality(8,17)

Patients are more likely to participate in a cardiac rehabilitation program if their physician strongly recommends it. Males are more likely than females to participate, and those with less severe cardiovascular disease are more likely to participate in an exercise program(17,20,21)

Cardiac rehabilitation services after MI are used commonly by Medicare patients.(20,21) In 2008, the authors of a retrospective study of Medicare beneficiaries with an MI (N = 158,991) found that 14% (n = 22,735) attended cardiac rehabilitation within 1 year of MI diagnosis. Those with a diagnosis of depression (28%) were 3.9 times more likely to attend cardiac rehabilitation and complete the program than those without depression(21)
Following MI, 25% of patients experience angina within 1 month(10)

Most survivors of MI can resume their normal ADLs within 6 to 8 weeks of an MI. Overall prognosis is worse for older adult patients (i.e., over the age of 80), patients with other cardiovascular or respiratory diseases or diabetes mellitus, and patients with an anterior location of the MI(1,2,8)

Main factors to consider for the post-MI  patient’s return to work, other than physical and psychological demands of work(14) –Age (most important) and sex –Medical factors -Previous MI, residual chest pain, poor left ventricular ejection fraction, low exercise capacity –Psychosocial factors -Education level -Employer attitudes -Psychiatrist recommendations –Economic/job factors -Heath insurance benefits, financial incentives, and work demands will be weighed compared to the risk of subsequent MI
Presence of anxiety negatively affects prognosis.(7) A high level of anxiety in the first 48 hours after hospitalization increases the chances of developing complications during hospitalization(7)
Patients with non-STEMI  may have lower in-hospital  mortality than those with STEMI, but a similar or worse long-term outcome(2)

Patients participating in cardiac rehabilitation programs after STEMI may have improved (decreased) QRS fragmentation on EKG(11) –Improved (decreased) QRS fragmentation is associated with increased survival rates and decreased future cardiac events(7)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Smoking cessation program, nutritionist, psychological counseling, back to physician for any abnormal symptoms or vital sign measurements
other considerations: Patient education on lifestyle modification is an important part of cardiac rehabilitation following MI: stress management, relaxation training, development of a tailored exercise program, smoking cessation, change to a healthy diet, and modification of CAD risk factors(7)
Provide a range of enjoyable types of exercise to meet the needs of persons of all ages and functional capacities, or those with significant comorbidity(7)
Allow patients to attend specific components of the cardiac rehabilitation program if they choose not to attend the whole program(7)
treatment summary: Inpatient physical therapy (phase I) –Patients usually begin a walking program in the hospital once cardiovascular status is stabilized. The inpatient cardiac exercise program may be started 2 days after MI and typically lasts 3 to 5 days, with the purpose of -initiating risk factor education -initiating self-care  activities and progress from sitting to standing to minimize deconditioning -initiating a supervised ambulation program to provide orthostatic challenge to the cardiovascular system -preparing the patient and family for discharge and transition to outpatient cardiac rehabilitation –Outpatient physical therapy (phase II) -Low-risk  patients may begin 2 to 4 weeks after hospital discharge (or 6 to 8 weeks later) depending on the severity of the diagnosis, and allowing time for the myocardium to heal and the patient’s system to adjust to any new medications -Fatigue levels after MI are lowest after 2 months of recovery(12) -Fatigue levels should be monitored to identify patients experiencing general fatigue who may need more rest and help to improve their sleep quality -The Multidimensional Fatigue Inventory (MFI-20) can be used to assess the patient’s physical fatigue, mental fatigue, and general fatigue, and reduce activity levels -Participants are often monitored via ECG telemetry,and BP is recorded during rest and exercise -This phase typically lasts 4 to 8 weeks, with an emphasis on -increasing exercise capacity in a safe and progressive manner -enhancing cardiac function and reducing cardiac expenditure -improving metabolic responses to physical activity -reducing the patient’s anxiety and depression -progressing patient to an independent exercise regimen -Supervised cardiac exercise therapy may decrease the recovery time needed to prevent fatigue(8,16) –Community-based  cardiac rehabilitation (phase III) -Supervised exercise programs are often continued in a community setting, although HR and cardiac rhythm are not monitored by telemetry. Patients are taught and encouraged to self-monitor  their HR. BP may be monitored in some patients, as indicated -The purpose of this phase is to continue to improve or maintain fitness levels achieved during phase II -Patients are advised to incorporate daily physical activity into their own preferred leisure activities, such as swimming, hiking, jogging, cycling, and cross-country  skiing

Supervised cardiac rehabilitation exercise programs may begin within 2 to 3 weeks after MI and typically last 2 to 3 months.(8,16,17)A self-directed  walking program may be recommended if the patient is unable to begin a supervised exercise training program on discharge from the hospital because of potential complications(8) –For more detailed information on cardiac rehabilitation following open heart surgery in adults, see  Clinical Review ... desired outcomes: Increased patient knowledge regarding cardiac risk factors and post-MI  precautions

Facilitate return to prior level of function–Cantril Ladder of Life–Quality of Life Index (QLI)–Seattle Angina Questionnaire–Health Belief Questionnaire–Cardiac Event Threat Questionnaire–Borg RPE Scale(8)
Return to recreational sports and activities–Exercise testing–6MWT

maintenance or prevention: The American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association guidelines stress the importance of primary prevention. Regularly perform a risk factor assessment.Secondary prevention interventions aimed at preventing recurrent events in patients who survive include physical activity 30 min. 5 days/week, weight management, and lifestyle changes to increase daily activity level Patients should be encouraged to maintain a healthy lifestyle including a balanced diet, physical activity and exercise, and avoiding risk factors including obesity and smoking
Exercise training before MI has been found effective at “changing aerobic capacity and left ventricular morphology and function” in animal subjects

Participation in an exercise program, smoking cessation, weight loss, proper nutrition, maintaining appropriate cholesterol levels and BP, and reducing stress can all help to prevent MI and prevent recurrence(2)

Structured discharge planning should be implemented to enhance communication and facilitate the transition of the patient from the hospital to the outpatient environment. It should include a review of medications, referral for exercise-based  cardiac rehabilitation, activity recommendations, education on lifestyle modifications and recognition of cardiac symptoms, and a clear follow-up  plan with all healthcare providers involved in the patient’s care Noncompliance with medications is common in patients following MI and is associated with increased mortality risk

Having a mentor can be beneficial for patients recovering from MI, especially in rural areas where cardiac rehabilitation programs are less accessible. In 2014, researchers of a study in Sweden found that smokers who had mentors quit smoking. Further research is needed in this area to evaluate lifestyle changes due to mentorship(13)
